content: Promises of a Bicultural Mom As an American citizen born to Punjabi immigrants, my perspective on parenting is ever-evolving Nami Thompson Blocked Unblock Follow Following Feb 20 Photo: ImagesBazaar/Brand X Pictures/Getty I am a grilled cheese sandwich with onions and chili peppers stuffed inside. I am a salwar kameez suit on a hot Colorado day. I am naan and cha left out for Santa on Christmas Eve. I am a reincarnated storyteller with mixed-texture hair that braids two languages, two histories, and two value systems together into the synthesis of one identity. As a Punjabi Sikh and the first in my family born in the United States, I inhabit both American and Punjabi cultures equally. It can be hard to reconcile some of the paradoxes within. I feel overly scrutinized, distrusted, and stereotyped, but I’m also exotic—an outside-the-box thinker in possession of ancient secrets. In short, I am Punjabi-American. “Be careful, Mom,” I’ll say after our president tweets some new slur. My mother responds with, “What the hell are you talking about?” While I worry over every new political debacle, my mom, a whole-ass immigrant, has accepted the constant threat of violence against her and my papa; it’s the price they pay for living here. I fear for the lives and safety of my family, but my mom lectures me for being afraid. She says, “You were born a U.S. citizen. No one can touch you.” Indeed, as a citizen, I have greater power to harm more people on this planet than most. It’s not that being a citizen of color confers rights that cannot be taken away; after all, even U.S.-born Asian people have had their citizenship revoked more than once by U.S. courts. But my fellow citizens and I ignore the footprint of global war, occupation, and colonization. In my name, Native Americans and people living in underdeveloped countries experience industrial pollution, enslavement, famine, communicable disease, genocide, and civil war. In turn, U.S. law enforcement buys and sells weapons of war in order to use military tactics against its most active protesters. I have witnessed parenting practices that both benefit my life and recycle damaging behavior back into the world. What does this mean for me as a bicultural mother living in the unclaimed territory caught between all this fuckery? I both perpetuate and endure cycles of imperial violence. I have witnessed parenting practices that both benefit my life and recycle damaging behavior back into the world. As a woman and mother balancing two cultures, I’ve found that my bicultural experience has made me vastly aware of a few things. Here’s what I’ve noticed and the promises I vow to keep — for myself and my child. Some of these values and promises may seem at odds. If they do, they reflect my reality as someone living inside two cultural systems at once. Vaccines and health care I never take a living, breathing baby for granted. I will never take health care — including vaccines — for granted, either. As a child, I went to gurdwara every Sunday among adults who had polio injuries or smallpox scars all over their faces. Their children are my friends and those friends were nearly not born. Additionally, I sometimes notice poor communication by U.S. family doctors, pediatricians, and public health professionals. These professionals don’t always take patients’ concerns seriously, particularly when they treat immigrants or black families, who have been historically lied to and experimented on by the medical system. As a bicultural mom, I will never deny a lived experience and demonstrable history of broken trust. Disposable diapers When my husband and I took prenatal baby care classes, the instructor taught us only about cloth diapers. They’re a “thing”—especially where I live. The class didn’t even mention disposable diapers. For us, cloth diapers just didn’t make sense. We didn’t have the time to devote to the process nor the finances to pay someone else to do it. My mom’s experiences of motherhood were the most influential in making this choice. I have an older brother who was born in India, and he wore cloth diapers as a baby out of necessity. It was exhausting for my mom to clean and dry them. There were no pick-up and drop-off cleaning services, and washing machines and laundromats weren’t widely accessible at the time. I see moms in the U.S. shame the choices my parents consciously made for me and romanticize the lifestyle they had no control over and did not choose. When I came around, my family was still somewhat newly immigrated, and my mom was working more than one job. She wasn’t going to haul poopy cloth diapers onto the bus and then to the laundromat. She was thrilled with the convenience of disposable diapers. To her, it’s ungrateful to scoff at them—no matter what you choose. I witness the virtue-informed choices U.S. moms make because they lack global context, and I also know firsthand the emotional pressure of trying to be a perfect parent. As a bicultural mom, I will never assume any parent shares my cultural lens. Bed-sharing Somewhere around the second week of my daughter’s life, I was tired of pulling her out of her bassinet for each feeding. I tried to get her to nurse while I slept. She hated it. I eventually put her on a sleep schedule (no crying was involved). She is almost four years old now and has happily slept through the night in her crib since she was five months old. She wakes up at 7, naps at 1, and goes to bed at 7. Just like her mom, she hates sharing her bed and wants lots of space to stretch out. Back in India, my mom used to share a floor cot with my brother because it’s what they had, and my dad traveled a lot for work. Years later, in the U.S., I had a crib in my parents’ room. It was aspirational: My parents felt privilege and pride that their baby had a place of her own to sleep. Once I outgrew the crib, I moved into the family bed. Not because my parents read an attachment parenting book—we literally had just one full-sized bed to share. I see moms in the U.S. shame the choices my parents consciously made for me and romanticize the lifestyle they had no control over and did not choose. As a bicultural mom, I will never assume I know more about another family than they know about themselves. My toddler’s toy auto-rickshaw. A Colorado-based company sells real-life auto-rickshaws for adult drivers. Does any child in any other country play with a toy yellow cab and grow up to buy one just for fun? Photo: Nami Thompson Formula and breastfeeding Just to give you a sense of how Punjabis feel about milk: When the doctor told my mother I was lactose intolerant, she started to cry. No matter what changes she made to her diet, I couldn’t tolerate breast milk. Back then, the only alternative to dairy formula was soy, and it was only sold at a natural food store that was more than one bus transfer away. My mom didn’t think twice about making sure I was fed. As a newborn, my daughter vomited after every feeding. When I called her pediatrician, he initially told me it was just spit-up, but when she projectile vomited Exorcist -style across his office, he referred us to a specialist. I didn’t have any luck making extreme changes to my diet, either. We later learned my child has FPIES , and no matter what I ate back then, she wouldn’t have been able to digest it. I suffered during breastfeeding, though not in the way other mothers often do. I produced plenty of milk, my baby’s latch was perfect, and it was painless, but I just plain hated breastfeeding. It was what I most looked forward to before becoming a mother, and when the time came, I experienced extreme and exaggerated depression during feedings. I later learned this was likely an iteration of dysphoric milk ejection reflex ( D-Mer ), which is understudied and underreported, so it’s hard to know how D-Mer presents in all breastfeeders. Switching to formula was lifesaving for me. Racing to be a fit and recovered mom shortly after birth makes other mothers feel like they have to keep up — and it generates a negative global impact for everyone. Some beautiful things happened when we shifted to formula. First, my child was nourished enough that she became more physically active and responsive. Second, her father bonded with her the way he wanted to. Our family joke is that he is a better mom than I am, and by bottle-feeding, he had more opportunities to develop a closeness with her, which they still share today. I am aware of the perceived differences in health outcomes between breastfeeding and formula feeding, and I’ve noticed a bitter and unnecessary debate in the U.S. I also recognize the problem of global famine and malnutrition, the need for clean water, and the fear of losing an infant before the age of one. As a bicultural mom, I will never demand a reason for how a parent chooses to feed their baby. Babywearing It was once common for new mothers and babies to rest for 40 days after childbirth. Originally, babywearing in India was meant for domestic workers, so they could resume their chores not long after childbirth. Inequity is built into the concept. Within the past two years, attachment parenting has gained popularity in India, just as it had in the U.S. a few years earlier. Indian moms are doing babywearing jogs and going to dance classes with infants in slings. That’s fun, it’s healthy, and I support it. An employer, however, might say, “If you can jog a 5K when your baby is two months old, you can come back to work,” thereby undercutting maternity leave and recovery time for mothers—not unlike what was asked of domestic workers in India. Racing to be a fit and recovered mom shortly after birth makes other mothers feel like they have to keep up — and it generates a negative global impact for everyone. I see the benefit and appeal of carrying your baby so you can bond, make nap time easier, calm their cries, and easily nurse, but that doesn’t mean the approach is for everyone. As a bicultural mom, I will advocate for a mother’s right to care for her child in any way she likes without sacrificing her perinatal needs. My cultures — American and Punjabi — express parallel attitudes toward motherhood, though those attitudes manifest differently. Both cultures demand motherly perfection and sacrifice, and they both judge mothers who express dislike for their parenting experience. On the Punjabi side, one generation pressures the next into pursuing a Westerner’s ideal image of child-rearing. A crib, bottles, rockers, a nursery. Whatever memsahib  — a married, upper-class woman — has. Both of these cultures have made motherhood a competition. On the U.S. side, moms post on Facebook about cultures that supposedly leave the mother’s placenta attached until it falls off or give their babies machetes (perhaps to cut the cord to the rotten placenta?). They’re attracted to whatever sounds most “natural.” Both of these cultures have made motherhood a competition. U.S. moms compete among each other while Punjabi moms compete with their own mothers. The most subtle similarity is the idea that motherhood survives everything. Both cultures teach that a mother can work three jobs, become a refugee, survive a natural disaster, get evicted, need stitches due to their baby having a machete… but no matter what, they’re still capable of giving their child the world just by being a loving mom. It’s a beautiful sentiment that may have subconsciously informed my choice to become a mother. “It’ll be fine as long as I shower her with love,” was the implicit message. But upon reflection, that is a terrifying and oppressive concept. It’s the assumption that mothers are immune to trauma, or can conjure up housing, food, and heat. It’s the assumption that mothers are superhuman, and the power of their love can cure all. That’s just not reality. As with all mothers, I choose to practice what feels true to me and change what I cannot tolerate any longer.
title_html: Promises of a Bicultural Mom
html:
Homepage
Homepage
Sign inGet started

  • Mind
  • Heart
  • Hands
  • Eyes
  • Soul
  • About

Promises of a Bicultural Mom

As an American citizen born to Punjabi immigrants, my perspective on parenting is ever-evolving

Nami Thompson
Feb 20

I am a grilled cheese sandwich with onions and chili peppers stuffed inside. I am a salwar kameez suit on a hot Colorado day. I am naan and cha left out for Santa on Christmas Eve.

I am a reincarnated storyteller with mixed-texture hair that braids two languages, two histories, and two value systems together into the synthesis of one identity.

As a Punjabi Sikh and the first in my family born in the United States, I inhabit both American and Punjabi cultures equally. It can be hard to reconcile some of the paradoxes within. I feel overly scrutinized, distrusted, and stereotyped, but I’m also exotic—an outside-the-box thinker in possession of ancient secrets.

In short, I am Punjabi-American.

“Be careful, Mom,” I’ll say after our president tweets some new slur.

My mother responds with, “What the hell are you talking about?”

While I worry over every new political debacle, my mom, a whole-ass immigrant, has accepted the constant threat of violence against her and my papa; it’s the price they pay for living here. I fear for the lives and safety of my family, but my mom lectures me for being afraid. She says, “You were born a U.S. citizen. No one can touch you.”

Indeed, as a citizen, I have greater power to harm more people on this planet than most. It’s not that being a citizen of color confers rights that cannot be taken away; after all, even U.S.-born Asian people have had their citizenship revoked more than once by U.S. courts. But my fellow citizens and I ignore the footprint of global war, occupation, and colonization. In my name, Native Americans and people living in underdeveloped countries experience industrial pollution, enslavement, famine, communicable disease, genocide, and civil war. In turn, U.S. law enforcement buys and sells weapons of war in order to use military tactics against its most active protesters.

I have witnessed parenting practices that both benefit my life and recycle damaging behavior back into the world.

What does this mean for me as a bicultural mother living in the unclaimed territory caught between all this fuckery? I both perpetuate and endure cycles of imperial violence. I have witnessed parenting practices that both benefit my life and recycle damaging behavior back into the world.

As a woman and mother balancing two cultures, I’ve found that my bicultural experience has made me vastly aware of a few things. Here’s what I’ve noticed and the promises I vow to keep — for myself and my child. Some of these values and promises may seem at odds. If they do, they reflect my reality as someone living inside two cultural systems at once.

Vaccines and health care

I never take a living, breathing baby for granted. I will never take health care — including vaccines — for granted, either. As a child, I went to gurdwara every Sunday among adults who had polio injuries or smallpox scars all over their faces. Their children are my friends and those friends were nearly not born.

Additionally, I sometimes notice poor communication by U.S. family doctors, pediatricians, and public health professionals. These professionals don’t always take patients’ concerns seriously, particularly when they treat immigrants or black families, who have been historically lied to and experimented on by the medical system.

As a bicultural mom, I will never deny a lived experience and demonstrable history of broken trust.

Disposable diapers

When my husband and I took prenatal baby care classes, the instructor taught us only about cloth diapers. They’re a “thing”—especially where I live. The class didn’t even mention disposable diapers.

For us, cloth diapers just didn’t make sense. We didn’t have the time to devote to the process nor the finances to pay someone else to do it.

My mom’s experiences of motherhood were the most influential in making this choice. I have an older brother who was born in India, and he wore cloth diapers as a baby out of necessity. It was exhausting for my mom to clean and dry them. There were no pick-up and drop-off cleaning services, and washing machines and laundromats weren’t widely accessible at the time.

I see moms in the U.S. shame the choices my parents consciously made for me and romanticize the lifestyle they had no control over and did not choose.

When I came around, my family was still somewhat newly immigrated, and my mom was working more than one job. She wasn’t going to haul poopy cloth diapers onto the bus and then to the laundromat. She was thrilled with the convenience of disposable diapers. To her, it’s ungrateful to scoff at them—no matter what you choose.

I witness the virtue-informed choices U.S. moms make because they lack global context, and I also know firsthand the emotional pressure of trying to be a perfect parent.

As a bicultural mom, I will never assume any parent shares my cultural lens.

Bed-sharing

Somewhere around the second week of my daughter’s life, I was tired of pulling her out of her bassinet for each feeding. I tried to get her to nurse while I slept. She hated it. I eventually put her on a sleep schedule (no crying was involved). She is almost four years old now and has happily slept through the night in her crib since she was five months old. She wakes up at 7, naps at 1, and goes to bed at 7. Just like her mom, she hates sharing her bed and wants lots of space to stretch out.

Back in India, my mom used to share a floor cot with my brother because it’s what they had, and my dad traveled a lot for work. Years later, in the U.S., I had a crib in my parents’ room. It was aspirational: My parents felt privilege and pride that their baby had a place of her own to sleep. Once I outgrew the crib, I moved into the family bed. Not because my parents read an attachment parenting book—we literally had just one full-sized bed to share.

I see moms in the U.S. shame the choices my parents consciously made for me and romanticize the lifestyle they had no control over and did not choose.

As a bicultural mom, I will never assume I know more about another family than they know about themselves.

Formula and breastfeeding

Just to give you a sense of how Punjabis feel about milk: When the doctor told my mother I was lactose intolerant, she started to cry. No matter what changes she made to her diet, I couldn’t tolerate breast milk. Back then, the only alternative to dairy formula was soy, and it was only sold at a natural food store that was more than one bus transfer away. My mom didn’t think twice about making sure I was fed.

As a newborn, my daughter vomited after every feeding. When I called her pediatrician, he initially told me it was just spit-up, but when she projectile vomited Exorcist-style across his office, he referred us to a specialist. I didn’t have any luck making extreme changes to my diet, either. We later learned my child has FPIES, and no matter what I ate back then, she wouldn’t have been able to digest it.

I suffered during breastfeeding, though not in the way other mothers often do. I produced plenty of milk, my baby’s latch was perfect, and it was painless, but I just plain hated breastfeeding. It was what I most looked forward to before becoming a mother, and when the time came, I experienced extreme and exaggerated depression during feedings. I later learned this was likely an iteration of dysphoric milk ejection reflex (D-Mer), which is understudied and underreported, so it’s hard to know how D-Mer presents in all breastfeeders. Switching to formula was lifesaving for me.

Racing to be a fit and recovered mom shortly after birth makes other mothers feel like they have to keep up — and it generates a negative global impact for everyone.

Some beautiful things happened when we shifted to formula. First, my child was nourished enough that she became more physically active and responsive. Second, her father bonded with her the way he wanted to. Our family joke is that he is a better mom than I am, and by bottle-feeding, he had more opportunities to develop a closeness with her, which they still share today.

I am aware of the perceived differences in health outcomes between breastfeeding and formula feeding, and I’ve noticed a bitter and unnecessary debate in the U.S. I also recognize the problem of global famine and malnutrition, the need for clean water, and the fear of losing an infant before the age of one.

As a bicultural mom, I will never demand a reason for how a parent chooses to feed their baby.

Babywearing

It was once common for new mothers and babies to rest for 40 days after childbirth. Originally, babywearing in India was meant for domestic workers, so they could resume their chores not long after childbirth. Inequity is built into the concept. Within the past two years, attachment parenting has gained popularity in India, just as it had in the U.S. a few years earlier. Indian moms are doing babywearing jogs and going to dance classes with infants in slings. That’s fun, it’s healthy, and I support it.

An employer, however, might say, “If you can jog a 5K when your baby is two months old, you can come back to work,” thereby undercutting maternity leave and recovery time for mothers—not unlike what was asked of domestic workers in India. Racing to be a fit and recovered mom shortly after birth makes other mothers feel like they have to keep up — and it generates a negative global impact for everyone. I see the benefit and appeal of carrying your baby so you can bond, make nap time easier, calm their cries, and easily nurse, but that doesn’t mean the approach is for everyone.

As a bicultural mom, I will advocate for a mother’s right to care for her child in any way she likes without sacrificing her perinatal needs.

My cultures — American and Punjabi — express parallel attitudes toward motherhood, though those attitudes manifest differently. Both cultures demand motherly perfection and sacrifice, and they both judge mothers who express dislike for their parenting experience.

On the Punjabi side, one generation pressures the next into pursuing a Westerner’s ideal image of child-rearing. A crib, bottles, rockers, a nursery. Whatever memsahib — a married, upper-class woman — has.

Both of these cultures have made motherhood a competition.

On the U.S. side, moms post on Facebook about cultures that supposedly leave the mother’s placenta attached until it falls off or give their babies machetes (perhaps to cut the cord to the rotten placenta?). They’re attracted to whatever sounds most “natural.”

Both of these cultures have made motherhood a competition. U.S. moms compete among each other while Punjabi moms compete with their own mothers.

The most subtle similarity is the idea that motherhood survives everything. Both cultures teach that a mother can work three jobs, become a refugee, survive a natural disaster, get evicted, need stitches due to their baby having a machete… but no matter what, they’re still capable of giving their child the world just by being a loving mom. It’s a beautiful sentiment that may have subconsciously informed my choice to become a mother. “It’ll be fine as long as I shower her with love,” was the implicit message.

But upon reflection, that is a terrifying and oppressive concept. It’s the assumption that mothers are immune to trauma, or can conjure up housing, food, and heat. It’s the assumption that mothers are superhuman, and the power of their love can cure all. That’s just not reality.

As with all mothers, I choose to practice what feels true to me and change what I cannot tolerate any longer.

  • Psychology
  • Self
  • Culture

  • Nami Thompson

    Medium member since Nov 2018

    Punjabi | Sikh | New Yorker | The Last Knicks Fan | Currently living in Boulder, CO. I believe in play as an act of resistance. patreon.com/NamiThompson

title: Promises of a Bicultural Mom
content_html:
Promises of a Bicultural Mom

As an American citizen born to Punjabi immigrants, my perspective on parenting is ever-evolving

Nami Thompson
Feb 20

I am a grilled cheese sandwich with onions and chili peppers stuffed inside. I am a salwar kameez suit on a hot Colorado day. I am naan and cha left out for Santa on Christmas Eve.

I am a reincarnated storyteller with mixed-texture hair that braids two languages, two histories, and two value systems together into the synthesis of one identity.

As a Punjabi Sikh and the first in my family born in the United States, I inhabit both American and Punjabi cultures equally. It can be hard to reconcile some of the paradoxes within. I feel overly scrutinized, distrusted, and stereotyped, but I’m also exotic—an outside-the-box thinker in possession of ancient secrets.

In short, I am Punjabi-American.

“Be careful, Mom,” I’ll say after our president tweets some new slur.

My mother responds with, “What the hell are you talking about?”

While I worry over every new political debacle, my mom, a whole-ass immigrant, has accepted the constant threat of violence against her and my papa; it’s the price they pay for living here. I fear for the lives and safety of my family, but my mom lectures me for being afraid. She says, “You were born a U.S. citizen. No one can touch you.”

Not because my parents read an attachment parenting book—we literally had just one full-sized bed to share.

Racing to be a fit and recovered mom shortly after birth makes other mothers feel like they have to keep up — and it generates a negative global impact for everyone. I see the benefit and appeal of carrying your baby so you can bond, make nap time easier, calm their cries, and easily nurse, but that doesn’t mean the approach is for everyone.

As a bicultural mom, I will advocate for a mother’s right to care for her child in any way she likes without sacrificing her perinatal needs.

My cultures — American and Punjabi — express parallel attitudes toward motherhood, though those attitudes manifest differently. Both cultures demand motherly perfection and sacrifice, and they both judge mothers who express dislike for their parenting experience.

On the Punjabi side, one generation pressures the next into pursuing a Westerner’s ideal image of child-rearing. A crib, bottles, rockers, a nursery. Whatever memsahib — a married, upper-class woman — has.

Both of these cultures have made motherhood a competition.

On the U.S. side, moms post on Facebook about cultures that supposedly leave the mother’s placenta attached until it falls off or give their babies machetes (perhaps to cut the cord to the rotten placenta?). They’re attracted to whatever sounds most “natural.”

Both of these cultures have made motherhood a competition. U.S. moms compete among each other while Punjabi moms compete with their own mothers.

The most subtle similarity is the idea that motherhood survives everything. Both cultures teach that a mother can work three jobs, become a refugee, survive a natural disaster, get evicted, need stitches due to their baby having a machete… but no matter what, they’re still capable of giving their child the world just by being a loving mom. It’s a beautiful sentiment that may have subconsciously informed my choice to become a mother. “It’ll be fine as long as I shower her with love,” was the implicit message.

But upon reflection, that is a terrifying and oppressive concept. It’s the assumption that mothers are immune to trauma, or can conjure up housing, food, and heat. It’s the assumption that mothers are superhuman, and the power of their love can cure all. That’s just not reality.

As with all mothers, I choose to practice what feels true to me and change what I cannot tolerate any longer.
